An I/O Psychologist's Guide to R & Rstudio" description: "My January 16, 2024 METRO workshop is now a blog post, covering the essential 20% of R syntax for 80% of data analysis tasks. This blog post is designed for both R beginners and those seeking a refresher." date: 1-15-2024 categories: [R, Workshop] citation: url: https://sijan14.github.io/sijan_portfolio/posts/2024-12-31-R-Workshop/ image: computer.jpg draft: false # setting this to `true` will prevent your post from appearing on your listing page until you're ready! --- ## üåü Introduction In recent years, the R programming language emerged as the industry standard in social science research, owing to its robust statistical analysis tools, powerful data visualization capabilities, and a rich ecosystem of packages. Its open-source nature and emphasis on reproducibility further propelled its widespread adoption. This workshop, titled ‚ÄúR You Ready? An I/O Psychologist‚Äôs Guide to R and RStudio," was tailored for both R novices and those seeking a refresher, focusing on the essential 20% of R syntax that facilitated 80% of data analysis tasks. Participants were introduced to the RStudio environment and fundamental R syntax, followed by hands-on sessions covering data transformation (dplyr), data visualization (ggplot2), statistical analyses (lm, stats), APA-style reporting (markdown, apa, papaja), and text mining (stringr, tidytext). The workshop concluded with collaborative problem-solving sessions to reinforce the concepts learned. The aim was to introduce students and practitioners to the power of R to carry out basic and advanced analyses, along with the capability to visualize and report findings. ::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100vh;"} ::: ## üßπ Tutorial #1 (Cleaning) ### Getting Started Before diving into the transformations, let‚Äôs load the necessary package and dataset. You can download the [dataset](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1zUQf6jiZq7vq1GzktL0lIo__uaVj7Vhr/view?usp=sharing) to follow along. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Uncomment the next four lines if you haven't installed the package # install.packages("tidyverse") # install.packages("psych") # install.packages("lsr") # install.packages("apaTables") library(tidyverse) library(psych) library(lsr) library(apaTables) # Loading the dataset df <- read_csv("IBM HR Data.csv") # Checking all the column names names(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Age" "Attrition" [3] "BusinessTravel" "DailyRate" [5] "Department" "DistanceFromHome" [7] "Education" "EducationField" [9] "EmployeeCount" "EmployeeNumber" [11] "Application ID" "EnvironmentSatisfaction" [13] "Gender" "HourlyRate" [15] "JobInvolvement" "JobLevel" [17] "JobRole" "JobSatisfaction" [19] "MaritalStatus" "MonthlyIncome" [21] "MonthlyRate" "NumCompaniesWorked" [23] "Over18" "OverTime" [25] "PercentSalaryHike" "PerformanceRating" [27] "RelationshipSatisfaction" "StandardHours" [29] "StockOptionLevel" "TotalWorkingYears" [31] "TrainingTimesLastYear" "WorkLifeBalance" [33] "YearsAtCompany" "YearsInCurrentRole" [35] "YearsSinceLastPromotion" "YearsWithCurrManager" [37] "Employee Source" ``` ::: :::
### Sorting Data Sorting is often one of the first transformations you‚Äôll perform. Here‚Äôs how to do it in base R and tidyverse. ##### Option 1: Base R In base R, you can use the `order()` function to sort by one or more columns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Sort by age in ascending order index <- order(df$Age) df <- df[index, ] ``` ::: ##### Option 2: Tidyverse The `arrange()` function from dplyr is a more concise and readable option: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Sort by multiple columns: Age (descending) and DailyRate (ascending) df <- arrange(df, desc(Age), DailyRate) ``` :::
### Renaming Columns Renaming columns is another frequent task, especially when preparing data for analysis or visualization. ##### Option 1: Base R Use the `colnames()` function to rename specific columns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Rename the first column (age) colnames(df)[1] <- "how_old" ``` ::: ##### Option 2: Tidyverse The `rename()` function provides an intuitive way to rename columns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Rename "how_old" back to "age" df <- rename(df, "age" = "how_old") ``` :::
### Filtering Data Filtering rows based on specific conditions is crucial for focusing your analysis. Let‚Äôs filter for single employees earning over \$10,000 per month: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Filter rows where MaritalStatus is "Single" and MonthlyIncome > 10000 single_rich <- df %>% filter(MaritalStatus == "Single", MonthlyIncome > 10000) ``` ::: The pipe operator (`%>%`) from the tidyverse makes it easy to chain multiple operations.
### Summarizing Data Summarization provides insights into key metrics like mean and standard deviation. Here‚Äôs how to summarize the filtered data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # summarizing the subset data single_rich %>% summarise(Mean = mean(MonthlyIncome), SD = sd(MonthlyIncome)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 √ó 2 Mean SD 1 15043. 3200. ``` ::: ::: This calculates the average (Mean) and standard deviation (SD) of the MonthlyIncome column for the filtered subset.
### Subsetting Columns Selecting specific columns is often necessary to focus on relevant data or remove unnecessary variables. You can use the `select()` function from the **tidyverse** to keep only the desired columns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Keep specific columns df %>% select(Attrition, DailyRate, Department, Education) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 23,532 √ó 4 Attrition DailyRate Department Education 1 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 2 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 3 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 4 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 5 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 6 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 7 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 8 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 9 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 10 Current employee 370 Research & Development 4 # ‚Ñπ 23,522 more rows ``` ::: ::: This selects only the *Attrition*, *DailyRate*, *Department*, and *Education* columns. To drop specific columns, use the `select()` function with the negation operator `!`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Drop unnecessary columns df <- df %>% select(!c(EmployeeCount, StandardHours, Over18)) ``` ::: This removes the *EmployeeCount*, *StandardHours*, and *Over18* columns. ### Grouping Data by Variable Grouping rows is helpful for summarizing data by categories. Here, we‚Äôll group the data by EducationField and count the number of occurrences in each category. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Group by EducationField and count rows df %>% group_by(EducationField) %>% count() %>% arrange(desc(n)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 9 √ó 2 # Groups: EducationField [9] EducationField n 1 Life Sciences 9725 2 Medical 7393 3 Marketing 2541 4 Technical Degree 2105 5 Other 1311 6 Human Resources 446 7 9 8 3 1 9 Test 1 ``` ::: ::: This code: 1. Groups the data by *EducationField*. 2. Counts the rows in each group. 3. Arranges the groups in descending order by count (n). ### Recoding Variables Recoding variables is a common task when transforming categorical data into numerical or more meaningful labels. First, let‚Äôs check the frequency of each category in the *Attrition* column: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # View the distribution of Attrition table(df$Attrition) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Current employee Termination Voluntary Resignation 19714 96 3709 ``` ::: ::: You can use the `recode()` function from the tidyverse to assign new values to the categories: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Recode Attrition variable df$Attrition <- recode(df$Attrition, "Current employee" = 0, "Termination" = 1, "Voluntary Resignation" = 2) ``` ::: This transforms Attrition into a numerical variable with the following mapping: - 0: Current employee - 1: Termination - 2: Voluntary Resignation ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100vh;"} ::: ## üé® Tutorial #2 (Visuals) We will use **ggplot2** to create visually appealing scatterplots, apply faceting for multi-panel plots, and customize plots for better presentation. These techniques are essential for exploratory data analysis and communicating insights effectively. ### Scatterplots in ggplot2 Scatterplots are a powerful way to visualize relationships between two continuous variables. Here‚Äôs how to create a simple scatterplot of *YearsAtCompany* vs. *TotalWorkingYears* with points colored red: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Basic scatterplot ggplot(data = df) + geom_point(aes(x = YearsAtCompany, y = TotalWorkingYears), color = "Red") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: This code plots *YearsAtCompany* on the x-axis and *TotalWorkingYears* on the y-axis with red points. ##### Adding Aesthetic Mappings To add another dimension, such as coloring points by *MaritalStatus*, use the `aes()` function: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Scatterplot with points colored by MaritalStatus ggplot(data = df) + geom_point(aes(x = YearsAtCompany, y = TotalWorkingYears, color = MaritalStatus)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
### Faceting for Multi-Panel Plots Faceting allows you to split the data into panels based on a categorical variable. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Faceted scatterplot by JobLevel ggplot(data = df) + geom_point(aes(x = YearsAtCompany, y = YearsInCurrentRole)) + facet_wrap(~JobLevel, nrow = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: This creates separate scatterplots for each level of JobLevel, arranged in two rows.
### More Cusomization For this section, we‚Äôll use the built-in mpg dataset. To enhance a scatterplot, you can map multiple aesthetics (e.g., color and size), customize axis labels, and add a title: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Load the dataset data(mpg) # Scatterplot with multiple aesthetics and customizations ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = drv, size = cty)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.7) + # Add points with transparency # Customize axis labels and plot titles labs(title = "Fuel Efficiency vs. Engine Displacement", x = "Engine Displacement (L)", y = "Highway MPG", color = "Drive Type", size = "City MPG") + # Apply a theme theme_bw() + facet_wrap(~class) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Here‚Äôs what this code does: - Aesthetics: Maps drv (drive type) to color and cty (city MPG) to point size. - Labels: Adds a title, and custom axis labels, and modifies the legend titles. - Theme: Applies a clean, white background theme (theme_bw()). - Faceting: Creates facets for each vehicle class. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100vh;"} ::: ## üìà Tutorial #3 (Analysis) ### Summary and Frequency Tables Use `summary()` and `table()` to calculate basic descriptive statistics and frequency counts. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Descriptive statistics for numeric variables summary(df$WorkLifeBalance) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Min. 1st Qu. Median Mean 3rd Qu. Max. NA's 1.000 2.000 3.000 2.761 3.000 4.000 10 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Frequency table for categorical variables table(df$Gender) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 2 Female Male 1 1 9400 14120 ``` ::: ::: Using the `describe` function from the **psych** Package for Detailed Summaries of numeric variables ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Descriptive statistics for MonthlyIncome describe(df$MonthlyIncome) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` vars n mean sd median trimmed mad min max range skew X1 1 23516 6502.76 4705.99 4936 5666.19 3278.03 1009 19999 18990 1.37 kurtosis se X1 1 30.69 ``` ::: :::
### t-tests A t-test is used to compare the means of two groups. Here, we examine differences in *JobSatisfaction* between genders. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Filtering Gender df <- df %>% filter(Gender %in% c("Female", "Male")) # Perform t-test t.test(df$JobSatisfaction ~ df$Gender, var.equal = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Two Sample t-test data: df$JobSatisfaction by df$Gender t = -5.0624, df = 23511, p-value = 4.171e-07 alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Female and group Male is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: -0.10296313 -0.04548644 sample estimates: mean in group Female mean in group Male 2.681247 2.755472 ``` ::: :::
##### Effect Size Effect size provides a measure of the magnitude of differences. We calculate Cohen's D using the **lsr** package. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Cohen's D for JobSatisfaction by Gender cohensD(df$JobSatisfaction ~ df$Gender) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0.0674014 ``` ::: :::
### One-Way ANOVA ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used to compare the means of more than two groups. We analyze *JobSatisfaction* across *Department*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Convert Department to factor class(df$Department) # Check class ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "character" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} df$Department <- as.factor(df$Department) # Convert to factor # Conduct ANOVA anovaTest <- aov(df$JobSatisfaction ~ df$Department) summary(anovaTest) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Df Sum Sq Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) df$Department 2 1 0.363 0.299 0.742 Residuals 23499 28524 1.214 18 observations deleted due to missingness ``` ::: ::: ##### Effect Size after conducting the ANOVA, we apply Tukey's HSD to compare the *JobSatisfaction* between different levels of *Department*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Post-hoc Tukey's HSD test TukeyHSD(anovaTest) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Tukey multiple comparisons of means 95% family-wise confidence level Fit: aov(formula = df$JobSatisfaction ~ df$Department) $`df$Department` diff lwr upr Research & Development-Human Resources 0.021787253 -0.06179058 0.10536508 Sales-Human Resources 0.027838399 -0.05866972 0.11434652 Sales-Research & Development 0.006051146 -0.03093437 0.04303666 p adj Research & Development-Human Resources 0.8141109 Sales-Human Resources 0.7310521 Sales-Research & Development 0.9221490 ``` ::: :::
### Correlation Analysis The correlation between two continuous variables can be calculated using the `cor()` or `cor.test` function. Here, we calculate the correlation between *JobInvolvement* and *RelationshipSatisfaction.* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Calculate correlation, using complete observations only cor.test(df$JobInvolvement, df$RelationshipSatisfaction, use = "complete.obs") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Pearson's product-moment correlation data: df$JobInvolvement and df$RelationshipSatisfaction t = 5.1325, df = 23506, p-value = 2.882e-07 alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 95 percent confidence interval: 0.02068330 0.04622137 sample estimates: cor 0.0334578 ``` ::: :::
### Multiple Linear Regression A multiple linear regression model can be used to predict the value of a continuous dependent variable based on multiple independent variables. Here, we build a model predicting *JobSatisfaction*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Multiple linear regression model model1 <- lm(JobSatisfaction ~ age + Gender + JobLevel + MonthlyIncome, data = df) # Display the summary of the model summary(model1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = JobSatisfaction ~ age + Gender + JobLevel + MonthlyIncome, data = df) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -2.0440 -0.7585 0.2526 1.2248 1.4585 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) 2.777e+00 3.336e-02 83.237 < 2e-16 *** age -3.597e-03 8.127e-04 -4.426 9.63e-06 *** GenderMale 7.321e-02 1.468e-02 4.989 6.13e-07 *** JobLevel 6.273e-02 1.948e-02 3.220 0.00128 ** MonthlyIncome -1.412e-05 4.568e-06 -3.090 0.00200 ** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 1.101 on 23490 degrees of freedom (25 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.002353, Adjusted R-squared: 0.002183 F-statistic: 13.85 on 4 and 23490 DF, p-value: 2.77e-11 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Second model including EducationField as a factor variable model2 <- lm(JobSatisfaction ~ as.factor(EducationField) + age + Gender + JobLevel + MonthlyIncome, data = df) # Display the summary of the model summary(model2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: lm(formula = JobSatisfaction ~ as.factor(EducationField) + age + Gender + JobLevel + MonthlyIncome, data = df) Residuals: Min 1Q Median 3Q Max -2.0400 -0.7611 0.2494 1.2052 1.5089 Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error t value (Intercept) 2.683e+00 6.190e-02 43.347 as.factor(EducationField)Life Sciences 1.459e-01 5.333e-02 2.735 as.factor(EducationField)Marketing 8.328e-02 5.653e-02 1.473 as.factor(EducationField)Medical 5.383e-02 5.370e-02 1.002 as.factor(EducationField)Other 8.145e-02 6.036e-02 1.350 as.factor(EducationField)Technical Degree 5.170e-02 5.740e-02 0.901 as.factor(EducationField)Test 3.908e-01 1.101e+00 0.355 age -3.670e-03 8.132e-04 -4.513 GenderMale 7.362e-02 1.467e-02 5.018 JobLevel 6.450e-02 1.948e-02 3.311 MonthlyIncome -1.453e-05 4.568e-06 -3.180 Pr(>|t|) (Intercept) < 2e-16 *** as.factor(EducationField)Life Sciences 0.006240 ** as.factor(EducationField)Marketing 0.140708 as.factor(EducationField)Medical 0.316139 as.factor(EducationField)Other 0.177169 as.factor(EducationField)Technical Degree 0.367754 as.factor(EducationField)Test 0.722669 age 6.42e-06 *** GenderMale 5.27e-07 *** JobLevel 0.000933 *** MonthlyIncome 0.001472 ** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 Residual standard error: 1.1 on 23477 degrees of freedom (32 observations deleted due to missingness) Multiple R-squared: 0.00395, Adjusted R-squared: 0.003526 F-statistic: 9.31 on 10 and 23477 DF, p-value: 1.403e-15 ``` ::: :::
### Logistic Regression Logistic regression is used when the dependent variable is binary. We transform Gender into a binary variable and predict it based on *MonthlyIncome* and *JobLevel*. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Convert Gender to binary variable (Male = 1, Female = 0) df <- df %>% mutate(Gender = ifelse(Gender == "Male", 1, 0)) # Logistic regression model logit <- glm(Gender ~ MonthlyIncome + JobLevel, data = df, family = "binomial") # Display the summary of the logistic regression model summary(logit) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Call: glm(formula = Gender ~ MonthlyIncome + JobLevel, family = "binomial", data = df) Coefficients: Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|) (Intercept) 5.965e-01 3.214e-02 18.558 < 2e-16 *** MonthlyIncome 2.086e-05 8.476e-06 2.461 0.0138 * JobLevel -1.575e-01 3.611e-02 -4.363 1.28e-05 *** --- Signif. codes: 0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1) Null deviance: 31633 on 23503 degrees of freedom Residual deviance: 31589 on 23501 degrees of freedom (16 observations deleted due to missingness) AIC: 31595 Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Exponentiate the coefficients to get odds ratios exp(coef(logit)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (Intercept) MonthlyIncome JobLevel 1.8157319 1.0000209 0.8542492 ``` ::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100vh;"} ::: ## üìù Tutorial #4 (Reports) We will use the `apaTables` package to format analysis outputs according to APA guidelines and export them to Word documents. ### APA Style Correlation Table First, we create a correlation matrix using the `cor()` function for a subset of numeric columns from the dataset. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Subset of numeric columns for correlation analysis num <- df[, c("age", "DailyRate", "DistanceFromHome", "HourlyRate", "MonthlyIncome")] # Calculate the Pearson correlation matrix corr_matrix <- cor(num, method = "pearson", use = "complete.obs") ``` ::: Next, we use the `apa.cor.table()` function from the apaTables package to create a formatted APA-style table. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create and save the APA correlation table apa.cor.table(corr_matrix, table.number = 1, filename = "Correlation_table.doc") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Table 1 Means, standard deviations, and correlations with confidence intervals Variable M SD 1 2 3 4 1. age 0.25 0.43 2. DailyRate 0.20 0.45 -.30 [-.94, .79] 3. DistanceFromHome 0.20 0.45 -.33 -.27 [-.94, .78] [-.93, .80] 4. HourlyRate 0.20 0.44 -.35 -.20 -.21 [-.94, .77] [-.92, .83] [-.92, .83] 5. MonthlyIncome 0.24 0.44 .24 -.35 -.32 -.35 [-.81, .93] [-.94, .77] [-.94, .78] [-.94, .77] Note. M and SD are used to represent mean and standard deviation, respectively. Values in square brackets indicate the 95% confidence interval. The confidence interval is a plausible range of population correlations that could have caused the sample correlation (Cumming, 2014). * indicates p < .05. ** indicates p < .01. ``` ::: ::: The above code will generate a Word document with the correlation table in APA format, and the file will be saved as "Correlation_table.doc".
### APA Style ANOVA Table We will use the `apa.aov.table()` function to format the ANOVA results into an APA-style table and save it to a Word document. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create and save the APA ANOVA table apa.aov.table(anovaTest, table.number = 2, filename = "Anova_table.doc") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Table 2 ANOVA results using df$JobSatisfaction as the dependent variable Predictor SS df MS F p partial_eta2 (Intercept) 7439.59 1 7439.59 6128.95 .000 df$Department 0.73 2 0.36 0.30 .742 .00 Error 28524.14 23499 1.21 CI_90_partial_eta2 [.00, .00] Note: Values in square brackets indicate the bounds of the 90% confidence interval for partial eta-squared ``` ::: ::: This will generate a Word document containing the APA-formatted ANOVA table, saved as "Anova_table.doc". ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ::: {style="display: flex; justify-content: center; align-items: center; height: 100vh;"} ::: ## üí≠ Conclusion In this blog post, we covered key techniques for data manipulation, analysis, and reporting in R. We started with basic operations such as sorting, filtering, and renaming columns using both base R and the dplyr package. We then explored advanced visualization with ggplot2, creating customized scatterplots and faceted plots. The analysis section demonstrated t-tests, ANOVA, regression models, and post-hoc tests to analyze relationships in the data. We also learned how to create APA-style tables for correlation matrices and ANOVA results using the apaTables package. While we‚Äôve only scratched the surface of what we can do with R, these tutorials should provide a robust foundation for conducting data analysis in research, business, and academic contexts, while hopefully mitigating initial anxieties associated with learning to code. Happy coding! ## üîó Reference Wickham, H., & Grolemund, G. (2017). *R for data science: Import, tidy, transform, visualize, and model data* (1st ed.). O'Reilly Media.
